text: the bill as amended is passed getting an
immigration bill to the Senate was no
easy task and what lies ahead on the
path to overhauling immigration law is
sure to continue firing up constituents
on both sides with political maneuvering
not easily deciphered by the average
voter coming almost three decades after
the last major change to immigration law
this bill will need to be passed by the
House of Representatives before it can
become a law but making it up those
steps may prove to be the biggest
challenge yet the house is not going to
take up and vote on whatever the Senate
passes we're gonna do our own bill the
Senate bill lays out a 13-year process
through which people living in the US
without legal status could apply to
become citizens the path to citizenship
is unfair despite opposition 14
Republican senators were convinced to
support the bill suede is part by an
amendment that dedicates 40 billion
dollars to the hiring of 20,000 new
Border Patrol agents and building 700
miles of fencing but that may not be
enough to secure Republican votes in the
house where many disagree with any sort
of path to citizenship we could be stuck
with a very bad bill on the way to the
president citizenship has become the
most controversial point in the
negotiations and many House Republicans
have vowed to remove it entirely
meanwhile Democrats have signaled that
move would be a deal-breaker
there are a few provisions that are
popular in both chambers like requiring
an electronic verification system for
employers instituting a merit-based
point system for legal immigration and
issuing more temporary visas for both
high tech and low skilled workers though
there is disagreement over how many of
each kind there's still a long way to go
before any immigration bill can become
law
but if one does pass it will be the
first plan in decades to address the
status of more than 11 million people
living in the United States illegally
